Plausible gradation among dove species explopitation of urban environments with Rock Pigeon in Highly Urban, Collared in Medium, and mourning utilizing lower intesity urban environments to more natural areas (pers. com R.E. Mirarchi). So included in med and low urban.  AMU Buffer applied based on mobility index. Amy Silvano 26may05

Romagosa, Christina Margarita. 2012. Eurasian Collared-Dove (Streptopelia decaocto), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu.prox.lib.ncsu.edu/bna/species/630

doi:10.2173/bna.630
references.A81COO01SEGP: Coombs, C.F.B., A.J. Isaacson, R.K. Murton, R.J.P. Thearle, and N.J. Westwood. 1981. Collared doves (Streptopelia decaocto) in urban habitats. Journal of Applied Ecology. 18: 14-62
references.A93HEN01SEGP: Hengeveld, R. 1993. What to do about the North American invasion by the Collared-Dove. Journal of Field Ornithology. 64: 477-489
references.B02ROM01SEGP: Romagosa, C.M. 2002.  Eurasion Collared-Dove (Streptopelia decaocto). In The Birds of North America, No. 630 (A. Poole and F. Gill, eds.). The Birds of North America, Inc., Philadelphia, PA.

habitat_description: The Eurasian Collared-Dove (Streptopelia decaocto) is an introduced species that is expanding its range rapidly across North America.  It is associated with the vegetation and food available in developed areas as well as rural, agricultural areas where grain is available.  Therefore it is most commonly observed in suburban, urban, and agricultural areas.  While the species roosts and nests in trees, it is not associated with heavily forested areas (Romagosa, 2012).
